# Scale: Melodic in F (Mode: Super Locrian, Shape: E)

## Overview
The Melodic scale in F, specifically in the mode of Super Locrian and the shape of E, is a unique and interesting scale that offers a distinct sound. By exploring this scale, musicians can add a different flavor to their compositions and improvisations. In this reference sheet, we will delve into the notes and intervals that make up this scale, the genres in which it is commonly utilized, and a few examples of songs where this scale is prominent.

## Notes and Intervals
The Melodic scale in F, Super Locrian mode, and shape E consists of the following notes and intervals:
- F (root note)
- Gb
- Ab
- Bb
- C
- D
- E

## Common Genres and Musical Flavor
The Melodic scale in F, in the Super Locrian mode with shape E, is often used in genres that incorporate a fusion of jazz, fusion, progressive rock, and experimental music. Its dissonant and tense sound can add an element of complexity and unpredictability to musical compositions. This scale is commonly employed in pieces that require a sense of tension and release, creating a mood that is both haunting and intriguing.
